Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Obstructive Sleep Apnea in Atrial Fibrillation Patients

Trial_Design.evidence: randomised controlled trial was conducted in cardiology units, enrolling adult AF patients

Participants.evidence: conducted in cardiology units, enrolling adult AF patients

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned to either polysomnography (PSG) or home sleep apnea testing (HSAT)

Objective.evidence: This study aims to evaluate OSA prevalence and diagnostic strategies in AF populations.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was OSA prevalence, measured over a 12-month period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the PSG group and 100 to the HSAT group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 98 participants in the PSG group and 97 in the HSAT group, using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: OSA prevalence was 65% in the PSG group and 60% in the HSAT group (mean difference = 5%, 95% CI -5% to 15%; p = 0.30).

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.

Funding.evidence: This trial was funded by the National Heart Institute.
